Ingredients: 

• 2 cups dried white beans (Great Northern or cannellini), soaked overnight and drained 
• 4 cups chicken or vegetable broth 
• 1 pound boneless pork shoulder, cut into chunks 
• 4 duck legs or duck confit 
• 4 sausages (such as Toulouse sausages or any flavorful pork sausages) 
• 1/2 pound pancetta or bacon, diced 
• 1 large onion, chopped 
• 4 cloves garlic, minced 
• 2 carrots, diced 
• 2 celery stalks, diced 
• 2 bay leaves 
• 2 sprigs fresh thyme 
• 1/2 cup breadcrumbs 
• Salt and black pepper to taste 
• Olive oil for cooking 
• Chopped fresh parsley for garnish 

Procedure: 

1. Preheat the Oven: 

Preheat your oven to 325°F (165°C). 

2. Cook the Beans: 

In a large pot, add the drained white beans and cover with the chicken or vegetable broth. Bring to a boil. 
Reduce the heat and simmer for about 30-40 minutes or until the beans are just tender. Drain the beans and set them aside. 

3. Brown the Meats: 

1. In a large ovenproof casserole dish or Dutch oven, heat a little olive oil over medium-high heat. 
2. Brown the chunks of pork shoulder, duck legs, sausages, and diced pancetta or bacon. Remove them from the pot and set them aside. 

4. Sauté the Vegetables: 

In the same pot, add chopped onion, minced garlic, diced carrots, and diced celery. Sauté for about 5 minutes until they start to soften. 
Add the thyme and bay leaves to the pot. 

5. Assemble and Bake: 

1. Return the browned meats to the pot with the sautéed vegetables. 
2. Add the cooked white beans and mix everything together. Season with salt and blackpepper to taste. 
3. Sprinkle the breadcrumbs evenly over the top. 
4. Cover the pot and place it in the preheated oven. 
5. Bake for about 2 to 2.5 hours until the cassoulet is bubbling, the top is browned, and the meats are tender. 

6. Serve: 

1. Remove the cassoulet from the oven, discard the bay leaves and thyme sprigs, and garnish with chopped fresh parsley. 
2. Serve the cassoulet hot, either directly from the pot or spooned into individual serving dishes. 

Cassoulet is traditionally served as a one-pot meal. It's hearty and rich, making it perfect for a satisfying family dinner. Enjoy your homemade cassoulet!
